content: The list provides names of independent counsels appointed by the special Division of the Court for Appointing Independent Counsels, United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia. It summarizes areas of investigation and results, along with cost information from audits by the Government Accountability Office. The cost information for investigations conducted by independent counsels is included, derived from audits by the Government Accountability Office or Senate Committee on Governmental Affairs reports. Total expenditures are calculated by adding up all costs, including amounts reimbursed for attorneys' fees. The list of independent counsels and special prosecutors appointed by the Special Division of the Court is included in the six-month GAO audit reports. Some independent counsels' identities and prosecutorial jurisdiction are kept confidential. Under previous federal law, information on appointments and investigation targets was generally confidential unless deemed otherwise by the Division of the Court. Total Costs of Investigations: There have been 20 independent counsel or special prosecutor investigations initiated under the statutory mechanisms originally enacted as part of the Ethics in Government Act of 1978. These investigations were kept confidential unless deemed in the public interest to release, or until an indictment or criminal information had been returned. The Department of Justice reports that investigations by special prosecutors and independent counsels have cost approximately $228,712,589 as of September 30, 2005. The statutory provisions for independent counsels expired in June 1999, and new independent counsels cannot be appointed. The Attorney General of the United States has the authority to hire and appoint special counsels. The Attorney General of the United States has the authority to appoint special counsels, who can conduct investigations and prosecutions on behalf of the United States. Regulations for special counsels were established in 1999, separate from independent counsels. The Attorney General can appoint special counsels for investigations and prosecutions. Cost figures for previous special counsel investigations have been released, including Robert Fiske's Whitewater investigation costing $6,073,000 and John Danforth's Waco incident investigation costing $15,536,793. Patrick Fitzgerald was designated as Special Counsel by the Justice Department in 2003. The Justice Department appointed Patrick Fitzgerald as the "Special Counsel" in 2003 to investigate the unauthorized disclosure of a CIA employee's identity. The expenses for the investigation could be paid from the permanent appropriation for Independent Counsels, totaling $902,118 as of September 31, 2005. The Independent Counsel investigations initiated under the former statutory mechanism resulted in no indictments in 12 out of 20 cases. Out of the 8 investigations that did lead to indictments, 3 did not involve the principal Government official initially targeted. Out of 20 independent counsel investigations, 12 resulted in no indictments. In the remaining 8 cases, the principal Government official indicted was either acquitted, had their conviction overturned, or the matter was dropped by the prosecution. Only two federal officials were convicted or pleaded guilty in the 20 independent counsel investigations. Michael Deaver was convicted of perjury, receiving a suspended sentence and a fine, while Secretary Cisneros pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor charge. In the Independent Counsel investigations, Michael Deaver was convicted of perjury and received a suspended sentence and a fine. Secretary Cisneros pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor charge, was fined, and later pardoned by the President. Special prosecutors and independent counsels appointed under federal law have included Arthur H. Christy, who investigated allegations against President Carter's Chief of Staff Hamilton Jordan for alleged cocaine use. The special prosecutor found insufficient evidence to bring criminal charges against President Carter's Chief of Staff Hamilton Jordan for alleged cocaine use. The investigation cost $182,000. Another investigation into allegations against President Carter's national campaign manager Tim Kraft found the allegations unsubstantiated, costing $3,300. Leon Silverman was appointed to investigate further. Leon Silverman was appointed to investigate allegations concerning President Reagan's Secretary of Labor Raymond J. Donovan, regarding bribery of labor union officials and connections to organized crime. The special prosecutor found insufficient evidence for prosecution, with the investigation costing $318,000. Further investigation began in 1985 to look into alleged false testimony. Investigated allegations against President Reagan's Attorney General nominee Edwin Meese, found no basis for criminal charges. Final report issued on September 20, 1984. Total cost of investigation was $7,200. Independent counsel Alexia Morrison was appointed to investigate allegations against former Assistant Attorney General Theodore B. Olson for giving false testimony to Congress regarding the EPA "superfund" inquiry. The investigation found insufficient credible evidence of false statements or obstruction of justice. The final report on the EPA "superfund" inquiry found no evidence of false statements or obstruction of justice, with legal obstacles hindering prosecution based on congressional testimony. The investigation cost $2,141,000 and also looked into allegations against former President Reagan aide Michael K. Deaver. Michael K. Deaver, a former aide to President Reagan, was convicted of perjury in 1987 for violating conflict of interest laws. He received three years probation and a $100,000 fine. The independent counsel's final report in 1989 revealed the investigation cost $1,552,000. Lawrence E. Walsh was appointed to investigate Lt. Colonel Oliver North and others in the Iran Contra affair. The independent counsel investigated potential criminal misconduct in the Iran-Contra affair, leading to guilty pleas from various individuals including Elliott Abrams, Carl R. "Spitz" Channell, Alan D. Fiers, Albert Hakim, Robert C. McFarlane, and Richard R. Miller. Several individuals involved in the Iran-Contra affair were convicted of federal offenses, including Thomas Clines, Clair George, and Lt. Col. Oliver L. North. Other key figures in the scandal included Albert Hakim, Robert C. McFarlane, Richard R. Miller, and Air Force Major General Richard V. Secord (Ret.). Several individuals involved in the Iran-Contra affair were convicted of federal offenses, including Lt. Col. Oliver L. North and Rear Admiral John M. Poindexter. Poindexter's five felony convictions were overturned due to tainted testimony, while North's convictions were remanded for review. Other figures indicted included Duane Clarridge and Joseph F. Several individuals involved in the Iran-Contra affair were convicted of federal offenses, including Duane Clarridge and Joseph F. Fernandez. President George Bush pardoned Casper Weinberger, Duane Clarridge, Clair George, Elliott Abrams, Alan Fiers, and Robert McFarlane in connection with the "Iran-Contra" matter. The final report of the Independent Counsel in the "Iran-Contra" matter was filed on August 4, 1993, with a total investigation cost of $47,873,400. James C. McKay was appointed to investigate allegations involving Franklyn C. Nofziger and potential violations of post-employment conflicts of interest related to lobbying activities for Wedtech Corporation. The Independent Counsel investigated allegations of influence peddling and lobbying activities for Wedtech Corporation, including Attorney General Edwin Meese's conduct and potential conflicts of interest. The report concluded that Mr. Meese's conduct likely violated criminal laws but no prosecution was recommended. The Independent Counsel's investigation found that Mr. Meese's conduct in the regional Bell companies may have violated criminal laws, but no prosecution was recommended. The investigation also looked into bribery and illegal gratuities involving the Aqaba Pipeline, but found insufficient evidence of wrongdoing. Nofziger's conviction was overturned on appeal due to technical issues in the indictment. The total cost of the investigation was $2,796,000. James R. Harper was appointed on August 17, 1987. James R. Harper was appointed on August 17, 1987 to replace Carl S. Rauh. The investigation was sealed with no indictments sought, costing $50,000. Another independent counsel appointed on May 31, 1989 with no indictments returned, costing $15,000. Larry D. Thompson was appointed on July 3, 1995 to investigate criminal conspiracy allegations. Thompson was appointed on July 3, 1995 to investigate allegations of criminal conspiracy involving favoritism and payments made to officials to influence the award of grants and subsidies in programs of the Department of Housing and Urban Development during the Reagan Administration. Former Secretary Samuel R. Pierce was involved in the investigation, but no indictment was sought for him due to admissions of mismanagement and corruption at the Department of Housing. Former Secretary Samuel R. Pierce was not indicted for mismanagement and corruption at the Department of Housing and Urban Development in 1995. Carlos A. Figueroa pleaded guilty to making false statements related to payments to HUD officials for influence in grant awards. Joseph A. Michael Queenan and Ronald L. Mahon, former HUD officials turned developers, were found guilty of bribery, conspiracy, and money laundering charges. Olsen, pleaded guilty to accepting illegal gratuities and bribery in relation to HUD funds allocation. Philip D. Winn also pleaded guilty to conspiracy charges for providing favors to HUD officials. Singletary and James G. Watt, were involved in illegal activities related to HUD, such as tax evasion and attempting to influence a federal Grand Jury. Philip D. Winn, a former HUD Assistant Secretary, pleaded guilty to conspiracy charges and was later pardoned by President Clinton. Victor R. Winn, a former HUD Assistant Secretary, pleaded guilty to conspiracy charges and was pardoned by President Clinton. The investigation cost $29,417,318 and the final report was released on October 27, 1998. Michael F. Zeldin succeeded Joseph E. diGenova to investigate Janet Mullins for potential violations of federal law. The investigation led by Independent Counsel diGenova found no evidence of criminal wrongdoing in the search of Bill Clinton's passport files during the 1992 presidential campaign. The investigation cost $3,089,082 according to the Government Accountability Office. Julie F. Thomas succeeded Robert W. Ray as Independent Counsel in the investigation of the Whitewater allegations, which began with Special Counsel Robert B. Fiske, Jr. and continued by Kenneth W. Starr. The investigation cost $3,089,082 according to the Government Accountability Office. The jurisdiction of Independent Counsel Starr was expanded multiple times to investigate various matters related to President Clinton and the First Lady, including Whitewater Development Corporation and the misuse of FBI files by White House staff. The jurisdiction of Independent Counsel Starr was expanded multiple times to investigate allegations related to the White House travel office, misuse of FBI files, false statements by White House Counsel Nussbaum, subornation of perjury, obstruction of justice, and intimidation of witnesses in the civil case Jones v. Clinton involving Monica Lewinsky. Results of the independent counsel investigations in the civil case Jones v. Clinton included guilty pleas and convictions of several individuals, with additional indictments related to failure to pay federal income taxes. On April 30, 1998, charges of failure to pay federal income taxes against Webster L. Hubbell, Suzanna Hubbell, Michael C. Schaufele, and Charles C. Owen were reinstated by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Additionally, on November 13, 1998, Independent Counsel Starr obtained a 15-count indictment against Webster Hubbell for concealment and false statements related to land deals in the 1980s. Counsel Starr obtained a 15-count indictment against Webster Hubbell for concealment and false statements about the Rose law firm's involvement in land deals in Arkansas in the 1980s. Hubbell pleaded guilty to tax evasion and false statements charges. Other individuals named in the indictment had their charges dropped. Additionally, Arkansas bankers Herbert Brancum and Robert Hill were acquitted on four charges. Other results of the independent counsel investigation included acquittals of Arkansas bankers Herbert Brancum and Robert Hill on four charges, Susan McDougal on obstruction of justice charges, and Julie Hyatt Steele's mistrial for alleged perjury and obstruction of justice in the Monica Lewinsky investigation. The "Whitewater aspect" of the investigation was concluded on June 30, 1999, with no indictments of the President or First Lady expected. Independent Counsel Ray confirmed this in a statement on September 20, 2000. Independent Counsel Ray confirmed on September 20, 2000, that there was insufficient evidence to prove that President or Mrs. Clinton knowingly participated in any criminal conduct related to Whitewater Development. The independent counsel found no evidence of criminal conduct by White House officials or First Lady Hillary Rodham Clinton in obtaining derogatory information. No criminal indictments were sought for White House aide David Watkins. On June 22, 2000, Independent Counsel Ray announced no criminal indictments for White House aide David Watkins or First Lady Hillary Rodham Clinton regarding the White House travel office. A report released on October 18, 2000, found insufficient evidence for criminal conduct. On January 19, 2001, Independent Counsel Ray declined further action. On January 19, 2001, Independent Counsel Ray announced the decision to not prosecute President Clinton in the Monica Lewinsky and Paula Jones-deposition matter. The court reaffirmed that White House aide Vincent Foster's death was a suicide and forwarded a report to the House of Representatives regarding potential grounds for President Clinton's impeachment.
